PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask. where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: Mrs. Margaret Thomas
Address: 124 Division
Birthplace: Lanark, Scotland

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? ...1906...
Where did you set up housekeeping? ...For 8 months in Saskatoon...
Where had you been living before that? ...Lanark, Scotland...
For how many people did you prepare meals? ...At first we came out to the home in April 1907 and...
How far was it to your nearest store? ...1/2 mile...
How often could a visit be made to the store? ...3-4 times a year...
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
Flour, rolled oats, sugar, syrup, lard, dried fruits, evaporated milk, tea, salt, pork...

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? ...Sometimes Quaker or Five Roses, whatever kind the store had on hand...
In what quantities did you buy it? ...10 lbs...
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? ...Not certain maybe $3...
How much did you use graham flour? ...Not sure...
Whole wheat flour? ...Not sure...
Was flour milled locally? ...Yes... How far away? ...What year?...
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? ...About 15 cents...
What other grain products did you use? ...Not sure...
Cornmeal? ...Not sure... Whole Wheat? ...Not sure... Farina? ...Not sure...
Other? ...Not sure...
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? ...Yes...
How did you grind it? ...Not sure...

Cornmeal, flour, sugar, salt, tea, coffee, butter, eggs, milk, meat, vegetables, fruit, preserves, canned goods, etc.

19. Were you reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

The following year, 1905, our food supply was very low, our crops were poor, and we had to rely on what we could grow ourselves. We could not afford to buy anything except what we needed for survival. To get enough money to buy more provisions, we had to work hard and save every penny we could. It was a difficult time, but we managed to survive.
